channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Alert level 1 impacts exercise routines for those in quarantine
item.description: With more people out on the streets in alert level 1, health authorities have had to re-think how people in managed isolation can get exercise.

item.title: Hundreds of Vanuatuans still stuck in New Zealand due to Covid-19
item.description: There are calls for the government to put more pressure on Vanuatu to repatriate its citizens with hundreds of seasonal visa holders stranded in New Zealand due to Covid-19.

item.title: Removal of Black Lives Matter posters 'an abuse of teacher power' - Councillor
item.description: An MP and an Auckland Councillor have joined the debate over Marist College, after some of its students accused the school of racism for removing Black Lives Matter posters.

item.title: Pike River Mine robot lost for 10 years finally recovered
item.description: A military robot that was lost in the Pike River drift five days after the mine exploded has been recovered.

item.title: Aged care faces crisis as nurses paid less than DHB peers
item.description: Aged care nurses who worked tirelessly to keep residents safe from Covid-19 say they face a critical staff shortages if their pay is not boosted to bring them in line with their DHBs.

item.title: 'Weeding on a giant scale' - tourism workers swap guiding for clearing wilding pines
item.description: Kayak and glacier guides who lost their jobs due to Covid-19 are turning their hand to clearing wilding pines.

item.title: Napier council's former CEO spent $4000 on farewell morning tea shout
item.description: A $4000 farewell morning tea shout for Napier City Council's former chief executive has raised eyebrows around the council table.

item.title: Wellington CBD speed limits reduced to 30km/h with public support
item.description: The move is part of a first wave of measures in the Let's Get Wellington Moving programme, a multi-billion dollar overhaul of transport in the city.

item.title: Hundreds of foreigners gathering in Hawke's Bay 'not sustainable' - Civil Defence
item.description: An increasing number of stranded foreign nationals are looking for work in Hawke's Bay, despite the season, and civil defence says it is like "watching a slow train wreck".

item.title: Government keeping options on table to aid stranded foreigners
item.description: More help for foreign nationals stuck in New Zealand because of Covid-19 is being considered by the government, says the immigration minister.

item.title: Police narrow search in investigation into missing woman
item.description: The investigation into missing woman Bridget Simmonds has reached a "critical point", as new information has come to light, police say.

item.title: Restaurants associated with slave trader Bully Hayes take differing approaches
item.description: An Akaroa restaurant named after infamous slave trader Bully Hayes now plans to change its name, but the owners of Queenstown's The Hayes say they have no intention of doing the same.

item.title: Māori woman allegedly racially abused at Ōwairaka while out on a walk
item.description: Police are investigating an attack on a wahine Māori with a moko kauae who was out on a walk in Auckland's Mount Albert.

item.title: Māori account for more than half of arrests by Armed Response Teams in trial
item.description: Armed Response Teams attended more than 8600 incidents over the six-month trial period - an average of 47 a day - police data shows.

item.title: Student says Marist College teachers are racist towards her peers
item.description: A Marist College student whose teachers tore down Black Lives Matter posters at the school says it's indicative of the systemic racism students deal with.

item.title: NZME board chair Peter Cullinane resigns ahead of shareholders meeting
item.description: Peter Cullinane says he resigned abruptly before the meeting after it was it was made clear big shareholders had lost confidence in him.

item.title: South Island winter tomato growers hit by carbon charges
item.description: Parts of New Zealand might soon struggle to find tomatoes in winter - and that's due to the cost of emitting carbon.

item.title: Hawke's Bay $1m drought funding 'doesn't go very far' - Rural Advisory Group
item.description: $1 million will be divided between thousands of Hawke's Bay farmers struggling with one of the worst droughts in a century.
